body: Also, if I've missed this in the code base feel free to toss a trout at me.  Part of this ticket was also to test the new issues templates :)

issue.title: Moving (almost as-is) Node2Vec from topologic
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the contribution guidelines: https://github.com/microsoft/graspologic/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-to-create-an-actionable-bug-report
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Closes #460 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This is a straight port of the node2vec implementation originally in https://github.com/microsoft/topologic/blob/dev/topologic/embedding/node2vec_embedding.py#L28

Docs have been adjusted to be numpy style and type hinting added throughout (not sure how that got away from us in the original).  

This is definitely worth revisiting after we get this in (it's blocking the automatic layout work from @bryantower) but I want to have conversations about:
- sklearn's fit/fit_transform and our usage thereof
- whether we should use nx or an adjacency matrix for this so we're consistent
- lack of unit test data files?
- THE NAME OF RETURN_HYPERPARAMETER AND INOUT_HYPERPARAMETER as;dlkjasdf;lkjasfd https://media1.tenor.com/images/17b05521f3a4399f91bb6b069fc6f67a/tenor.gif

#### Any other comments?

body:
i agree 💯 percent with this. 

Only other comment is sklearn has some array checking utils also that we can try to steal as much as possible too.
#571 will be able to make use of this as well

some notes (in progress) on input checking that may be useful for us in sklearn. all of these are in the public API: 
- [check_array](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.utils.check_array.html#sklearn.utils.check_array)
- [check_scalar](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.utils.check_scalar.html#sklearn.utils.check_scalar)
   - I see absolutely no downside to using this one in particular in like a million places. allows for max and min value specs, prints errors based on a name for the parameter that you pass, etc.
- [check_consistent_length](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.utils.check_consistent_length.html#sklearn.utils.check_consistent_length)
- [column_or_1d](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.utils.validation.column_or_1d.html#sklearn.utils.validation.column_or_1d)
- [check_random_state](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.utils.check_random_state.html#sklearn.utils.check_random_state)
- [check_symmetric](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.utils.validation.check_symmetric.html#sklearn.utils.validation.check_symmetric)
Dwayne: we should look into libraries with decorators that do this based on `typing`
hey @bdpedigo I am new, i want to contribute to this project, can i work on this ? With your guiding if it's possible ?

hi @aaitbr, welcome! could you give us some info regarding your experience with open source (e.g. github) and python? Then we can help you get started on this. 

Do you mind if I ask whether you found our project on one of the sites with "good-first-issues" or somewhere else?

@bdpedigo yes sure ! so in python i'm familiar with libraries numpy, pandas & scikit-learn .. i know a little Spark, and i'm motivated and open to any learn in python to improve myself. Yes I found this project by using "good-first-issues" key, I read the documentation i liked it then i installed it.

sounds good @aaitbr - 

as far as this issue goes, the goal is just to reduce the amount of input checking code we have across the library by refactoring that code to a utils or assertions module. 

I'm linking a few places you can see tons of input checking code:
https://github.com/microsoft/graspologic/blob/e465fa39ceb65156e3dea1d256fb566eb14aa215/graspologic/embed/base.py#L221

https://github.com/microsoft/graspologic/blob/e465fa39ceb65156e3dea1d256fb566eb14aa215/graspologic/inference/latent_distribution_test.py#L218

https://github.com/microsoft/graspologic/blob/e465fa39ceb65156e3dea1d256fb566eb14aa215/graspologic/simulations/simulations.py#L51

If you take this on, I'd recommend starting by focusing on `ValueError` checking - if you look above in this issue, we have discussed trying to set up `TypeError` checking once we get `typing` set up as well (see #504, which we could also use help on) using something like . Therefore, hopefully the type errors wont need checking at all if we can find a way to handle them with some sort of library that lets us just use decorators. 

I also link to a few input checking functions in sklearn that we can use for this project. 

As far as making PRs go, I'd recommend making small PRs (i.e. even if they only address one or two modules), because they will get reviewed faster and you'll get feedback faster. 

let me know if anything is unclear! like I said, #504 would also be another place we could use help - im not sure whether people have made much progress on it but I havent seen any PRs merged there.

Looks like this is still open, can I take a stab at it?

Have some experience in Python but am new to open source. To answer your earlier question @bdpedigo, I found this on one of the sites with "good-first-issues"

Hi @bradycargle, let me check.

@daxpryce is this taken care of in #504 and some other recent PRs?
